choices.text: Side effects of hydrochlorothiazide
Decreased metabolism of hydrochlorothiazide by lithium.
Increased renal tubular reabsorption of lithium.
Thiazide acts as an add on drug to lithium.

questions.text: A patient with bipolar disorder was treated with lithium. Hydrochlorothiazide was prescribed for his hypertension. He developed nausea, vomiting, coarse tremors and brisk reflexes 2 weeks after taking drugs. What is the likely reason for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased renal tubular reabsorption of lithium.

 

The most likely cause of the patient's symptoms, including nausea, vomiting, coarse tremors, and brisk reflexes, is increased renal tubular reabsorption of lithium. When hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, is administered alongside lithium, it can lead to decreased renal clearance of lithium by increasing its reabsorption in the renal tubules. This pharmacological interaction results in elevated serum lithium levels, potentially culminating in lithium toxicity. The symptoms of lithium toxicity closely align with those experienced by the patient, making this option the most plausible explanation for the clinical presentation observed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Side effects of hydrochlorothiazide: While hydrochlorothiazide can cause side effects like electrolyte imbalances and dehydration, its common side effects do not typically include the combination of symptoms seen in lithium toxicity (nausea, vomiting, coarse tremors, and brisk reflexes). These symptoms are more specifically indicative of lithium toxicity rather than direct side effects of hydrochlorothiazide.
 

Option B. Decreased metabolism of hydrochlorothiazide by lithium: Lithium does not significantly impact the metabolism of hydrochlorothiazide. The metabolism and clearance of hydrochlorothiazide are primarily renal and are not substantially altered by concurrent lithium use, making this option an unlikely cause of the patient's symptoms.
 

Option D. Thiazide acts as an add-on drug to lithium: There is no evidence to suggest that thiazide diuretics act as add-on drugs to enhance the therapeutic effects of lithium in the treatment of bipolar disorder. The interaction between hydrochlorothiazide and lithium that is of clinical significance relates to the effect on lithium's renal handling, rather than a synergistic effect on mood stabilization.
 

Educational Objective:

 

The key learning point from this scenario is understanding the pharmacological interaction between lithium and thiazide diuretics, such as hydrochlorothiazide, and how this interaction can lead to increased serum lithium levels and subsequent lithium toxicity.

questions.text: Stoppage of which of the following drugs can result in anxiety and insomnia causing discontinuation syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Venlafaxine

Discontinuation syndrome refers to a set of symptoms that can occur after abruptly stopping or significantly reducing the dose of certain medications, particularly those that affect neurotransmitter levels in the brain such as antidepressants.  Common symptoms of discontinuation syndrome include anxiety, insomnia, dizziness, irritability, flu-like symptoms, and sensory disturbances (e.g., "electric shock" sensations). The severity and duration of symptoms can vary depending on the drug's half-life, dosage, and the duration of treatment. Discontinuation syndrome is commonly noted with all antidepressants including SSRI, SNRI and MAO inhibitors. It is less frequently noted with fluxoetine because of its long half life. Gradual tapering of the medication under medical supervision is recommended to minimize the risk of discontinuation syndrome.

 

Explanation:

Option A: Venlafaxine: It is an SNRI (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), is known for its potent effects on both serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake. Discontinuation of venlafaxine, especially abruptly, can lead to a significant and distressing withdrawal syndrome characterized by anxiety, insomnia, and other physical and psychological symptoms. This is due to the rapid decline in neurotransmitter levels that had been maintained by the medication.

Option B. Fluoxetine: Less likely to cause severe discontinuation syndrome due to its long half-life, which provides a natural tapering effect.

 

Option C. Valproate: An antiepileptic drug that does not typically cause discontinuation syndrome related to mood alterations like anxiety and insomnia.

 

Option D. Olanzapine: While stopping antipsychotics like olanzapine can lead to withdrawal symptoms, they do not typically manifest as anxiety and insomnia linked to discontinuation syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

Venlafaxine discontinuation needs to be managed carefully to avoid severe withdrawal symptoms, often requiring a gradual tapering of the dose under medical supervision to mitigate the risk of discontinuation syndrome.

questions.text: Which antiepileptic drug can cause this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phenytoin

 

Option B:

 

Figure shows gum hypertrophy caused by Phenytoin. Phenytoin is an antiepileptic drug known to cause gingival hyperplasia as a side effect. This adverse effect is more commonly associated with phenytoin than with the other antiepileptic drugs listed. The exact mechanism is not fully understood, but it is thought to involve the stimulation of fibroblasts to produce more collagen and other extracellular matrix substances, leading to the overgrowth of gum tissue.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Carbamazepine: While carbamazepine can have several side effects, it is not typically associated with gingival hyperplasia.
 

Option C. Phenobarbitone: Phenobarbitone (phenobarbital), another antiepileptic drug, also does not commonly cause gingival hyperplasia.
 

Option D. Valproate: Valproate does not typically cause gingival hyperplasia as a side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational goal is to recognize the side effects associated with antiepileptic drugs, particularly phenytoin, which is known to cause gingival hyperplasia. Healthcare providers should monitor patients on phenytoin for this condition and educate them about maintaining good oral hygiene to help prevent or minimize this adverse effect.

 

Drugs causing gum hypertrophy are:

 

  • Phenytoin
  • Cyclosporine
  • Calcium channel blockers like verapamil, diltiazem and nifedipine

choices.text: More potently blocks 5HT2 as compared to D2 receptors.
Blood level below 350 ng/ml should be maintained to avoid agranulocytosis.
Should not be used along with Carbamazepine.
Should be discontinued if the WBC count is below 3,000/mm3 cells.

questions.text: All are true about Clozapine except
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood level below 350 ng/ml should be maintained to avoid agranulocytosis.

 

Explanation:

 

The false statement about clozapine is option B, which states that "Blood level below 350 ng/ml should be maintained to avoid agranulocytosis." This statement is not true because there is no specific blood level of clozapine that is associated with the risk of agranulocytosis, which is dose-independent adverse effect of clozapine. High plasma concentration of Clozapine increases the risk of seizures (dose-dependent). However, the usual plasma concentration required in many people is 300-600 ng/ml.

  • Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic drug that has high potency to block 5HT2 receptors as compared to D2 receptors. However, it also blocks D4 receptors, muscarinic receptors, alpha receptors and H1 receptors.
  • It suppresses both positive as well as negative symptoms of schizophrenia. It is the first FDA approved drug for anti-suicide indication.
  • It is used only as a reserve drug due to the risk of precipitation of seizures (even in non-epileptics) and agranulocytosis. Convulsions are dose-dependent adverse effects seen only at higher doses whereas agranulocytosis is independent of dose.
  • Clozapine should be started at low doses (12.5 mg) and gradually dose should be increased. Baseline WBC counts should be measured, and then weekly counts should be done at least for the first 6 months. When WBC count becomes less than 3000/mm3 or absolute neutrophil count becomes less than 1500/mm3, Clozapine should be discontinued. After discontinuation, weekly WBC counts should be measured for an additional 4 weeks.
  • It should not be used with Carbamazepine due to two reasons:
    • Carbamazepine induces its metabolism and thus decreases plasma concentration.
    • Carbamazepine has bone marrow suppressant action and can add to agranulocytosis caused by Clozapine.

questions.text: This figure represents the mechanism of drugs used in the treatment of parkinsonism. Which of the following options correctly represents the drugs shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A: Pramipexole, B: Entacapone, C: Selegiline, D: Carbi-dopa

 

Explanation:

 

The mainstay of treatment for Parkinson's disease is the use of dopaminergic medications, which increase the levels of dopamine in the brain. These medications can be

 

  1. Dopamine precursors: These medications are converted into dopamine in the brain and include levodopa (L-dopa) and its combination with carbidopa. Carbidopa prevents the breakdown of levodopa in the bloodstream (by inhibiting dopa decarboxylase enzyme), allowing more of it to reach the brain.
  2. Dopamine agonists: These medications mimic the action of dopamine in the brain and include pramipexole and ropinirole.
  3. MAO-B inhibitors: These medications block the breakdown of dopamine in the brain and include selegiline and rasagiline.
  4. Catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) inhibitors: These inhibit the metabolism of levo dopa and dopamine. These are used in0 combination with levodopa to prolong its effect. Examples of COMT inhibitors include entacapone and tolcapone.

choices.text: It is less damaging to intima on intravenous administration.
It can be injected in a drip of glucose solution.
It is a prodrug of phenytoin.
All the above

questions.text: Fosphenytoin is different from phenytoin as?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above 

 

Explanation:

 

Fosphenytoin offers several advantages over phenytoin, particularly in how it is administered:

 

  • It is a water-soluble prodrug of phenytoin, meaning it is converted into phenytoin once administered. This conversion allows it to be more versatile and manageable in clinical settings.
  • Less damaging to the vein intima: Fosphenytoin is less irritating to the veins compared to phenytoin, which is known for causing phlebitis and damage to the vein walls.
  • Can be mixed with glucose solutions: Unlike phenytoin, which precipitates in glucose solutions, fosphenytoin’s water solubility allows it to be administered with various diluents, including glucose, enhancing its usability in different infusion setups.
  • A, B, C: Each of these statements correctly describes how fosphenytoin differs from phenytoin, as detailed above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fosphenytoin provides critical advantages for intravenous use over phenytoin, particularly its solubility, less vein irritation, and flexibility in dilution options, making it preferable in emergency and hospital settings for rapid seizure control.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. He has sustained a significant head injury, characterized by a loss of consciousness and visible head trauma. The medical team is evaluating his condition and considering management options.

Considering the patient's head injury, which of the following drugs is contraindicated due to the potential for exacerbating his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Morphine

 

Option C:

 

In the context of a significant head injury with a loss of consciousness and visible trauma, Morphine is contraindicated due to its potential to exacerbate the patient's condition. Morphine, an opioid analgesic, can lead to respiratory depression, resulting in increased carbon dioxide (CO2) levels. Elevated CO2 can cause cerebral vasodilation, leading to an increase in intracranial pressure (ICP), which is particularly dangerous in patients with head injuries as it can worsen brain injury and increase the risk of brain herniation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Furosemide: A diuretic used to reduce fluid overload but not typically contraindicated in head injury. It does not have the same impact on ICP as morphine.

 

Option B.  Diclofenac: A non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for pain management. While NSAIDs can have their own set of considerations in trauma (e.g., concerns about bleeding), they do not directly increase ICP like morphine can.

 

Option D.  Mannitol: An osmotic diuretic specifically used in the management of elevated ICP in patients with head injuries. Mannitol helps to reduce ICP and is indicated, not contraindicated, in cases of significant head trauma where increased ICP is a concern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key educational takeaway is to recognize the contraindication of using morphine in patients with head injuries due to its potential to cause respiratory depression, leading to increased CO2, cerebral vasodilation, and a subsequent rise in ICP.

choices.text: It is a long acting µ -receptor agonist.
It is rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and is detected in plasma 30 minutes after oral administration.
The primary use of methadone is relief of chronic pain.
The onset of analgesia is 60 minutes after parenteral administration and 2-4 hours after oral administration.

questions.text: True statements regarding methadone are all, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The onset of analgesia is 60 minutes after parenteral administration and 2-4 hours after oral administration.

 

Methadone, a long-acting µ-opioid receptor agonist, is known for its extended binding to the µ-opioid receptors, which provides prolonged pain relief as well as effects like sedation and euphoria. It is rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract, detectable in plasma within 30 minutes after oral administration. Its peak plasma concentrations and the onset of analgesia can vary among individuals but generally occur much sooner than stated in option D. Typically, the onset of analgesia is about 10-20 minutes after parenteral administration and 30-60 minutes after oral administration, making option D incorrect.

 

Explanation:

 

Options A, B, C: All are accurate statements about methadone, describing its pharmacokinetics and primary uses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methadone provides extended pain relief due to its long-acting nature as a µ-opioid receptor agonist. The onset of its analgesic effects is faster than indicated in option D, which is critical for understanding its effective use in pain management and opioid dependency treatments.

choices.text: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

questions.text: Mrs. Kanchan, a 50-year-old female, has been prescribed both clomipramine and escitalopram for the treatment of depression and anxiety. Which of the following should be monitored in her due to the combination of these medications?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serotonin Syndrome

 

Option B:

 

Serotonin syndrome is a critical condition to monitor in patients prescribed both clomipramine, a tricyclic antidepressant, and escitalopram, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Clomipramine inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, while escitalopram primarily increases serotonin levels by inhibiting its reuptake at the synaptic cleft. The combined effect of these drugs significantly raises serotonin levels, which can lead to serotonin syndrome. This syndrome is characterized by symptoms such as agitation, confusion, rapid heart rate, dilated pupils, muscle rigidity, fever, and in severe cases, can be life-threatening.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Parkinson’s disease: Not directly related to the combined use of clomipramine and escitalopram.

 

Option C. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome: Typically associated with the use of antipsychotic drugs, not antidepressants.

 

Option D. Hyperpyrexia: While hyperpyrexia can occur as a part of serotonin syndrome, it is not a standalone concern with these medications outside of that context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When combining clomipramine with an SSRI like escitalopram, there is an increased risk of serotonin syndrome, a serious medical condition resulting from too much serotonin in the body. It is crucial to monitor for signs and adjust treatment if symptoms develop.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient complained of hearing voices and was started on haloperidol for the treatment of his symptoms. However, for the past few days, he has been very restless and constantly moving about. What is the most likely condition that the patient is experiencing?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Akathisia

 

Option A:

 

Akathisia is a movement disorder commonly associated with the use of antipsychotic medications, such as haloperidol. It is characterized by an inner sense of restlessness and an uncontrollable need to be in constant motion. Patients often describe it as a compelling urge to move, and they are frequently seen shifting their position or walking about. This condition typically appears shortly after starting the medication or after a dose increase. Akathisia is distressing and can adversely affect compliance with medication.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Tardive dyskinesia: This condition involves involuntary, repetitive movements of the face and limbs but typically develops after long-term use of antipsychotics, making it less likely in this acute setting.

 

Option C. Rabbit syndrome: Characterized by rapid movements of the lips and mouth, rabbit syndrome is associated with prolonged antipsychotic use, not acute symptoms following recent medication initiation.

 

Option D. Acute dystonia: While this involves sudden muscle contractions, it usually presents as twisted postures or abnormal movements of the face, neck, and eyes, rather than the restlessness and constant movement typical of akathisia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Akathisia is a significant side effect of antipsychotic medications like haloperidol, presenting as an uncontrollable urge to move and restlessness, often occurring shortly after the initiation or increase of medication. Monitoring and managing this side effect are crucial for patient comfort and treatment adherence. Propranolol is frequently used to treat this condition effectively.

choices.text: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is referred to his physician because of “blinking too much,” which his mother thinks she first noted >1 year ago. The boy states that he does not notice that it is occurring unless someone tells him about it. When he is nervous, it seems to worsen. He is embarrassed about it and wants to control it. What class of medications has been shown to worsen this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stimulants

 

Option D:

 

The symptoms described are characteristic of Tourette syndrome, a condition marked by repetitive involuntary movements and vocalizations known as tics. Stimulants, commonly prescribed for conditions like ADHD, can exacerbate tics in individuals diagnosed with Tourette syndrome. The use of stimulants in patients with Tourette's needs careful consideration, as they can increase the frequency or severity of tics.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Antipsychotic: These medications are sometimes used to manage severe tics, not worsen them.

 

Option B. Anti-Depressants: Typically, do not exacerbate tics and are used to treat co-morbid conditions like anxiety or depression in Tourette syndrome.

 

Option C. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs): Used to address associated symptoms of anxiety and depression but do not typically worsen tics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When treating patients with Tourette syndrome who require medication for coexisting conditions such as ADHD, careful consideration must be given to the choice of medication, as stimulants may worsen tic symptoms.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for delirium tremens in alcohol withdrawal in a patient with severe alcoholic liver disease is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lorazepam

 

Explanation:

 

  • Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome that can be life-threatening. Benzodiazepines are the first-line treatment for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms, including delirium tremens. However, in patients with severe liver disease, it is crucial to choose a benzodiazepine that is metabolized more safely in this population.
  • Lorazepam is preferred over other benzodiazepines like diazepam and chlordiazepoxide because it has a shorter half-life and undergoes glucuronidation, a metabolic pathway that is less affected by liver dysfunction. This makes lorazepam safer for patients with impaired liver function.
  • Thiamine (vitamin B1) is important to administer in patients with alcohol use disorder to prevent Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, but it is not the treatment of for delirium tremens.

choices.text: Nausea and vomiting

questions.text: The side effects of lithium in psychiatry practice includes all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypocalcemia


Hypocalcemia (low calcium levels in the blood) is not a side effect of lithium therapy. In rare cases, lithium may cause hyperparathyroidism and elevated parathyroid hormone levels, which can lead to hypercalcemia (elevated calcium levels in the blood).

Other options:

 

Lithium is a mood stabilizer commonly used in the treatment of bipolar disorder. The common side effects of lithium include:

 

Option A. Nausea and vomiting: Gastrointestinal disturbances, such as nausea and vomiting, are common side effects of lithium, particularly during the initial stages of treatment.

 

Option B. Tremors: Fine tremors are a well-known side effect of lithium therapy. These tremors may be dose-dependent and can be reduced by lowering the dose or by adding a beta-blocker.

 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: Lithium can interfere with thyroid function, leading to hypothyroidism in some patients. Regular monitoring of thyroid function is recommended during lithium treatment.

choices.text: Sexual dysfunction

questions.text: A psychotropic drug inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin is likely to cause which of the following side effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sexual dysfunction

 

Explanation:

 

  • SSRIs are commonly used to treat depression and anxiety disorders. They work by increasing the levels of serotonin in the brain, which helps regulate mood. However, SSRIs can also cause several side effects, including sexual dysfunction. This can manifest as decreased libido, difficulty achieving orgasm, or erectile dysfunction.
  • The other side effects listed (dry mouth, visual disturbance, and constipation) can be associated with other types of psychotropic medications but are not as commonly linked to serotonin reuptake inhibitors.

questions.text: Mirtazapine is useful in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Depression

 

MIRTAZAPINE

 

Explanation:

 

  • Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant drug.
  • It inhibits presynaptic α2 receptors and thus increases NA and 5-HT release due to inhibition of auto- and hetero- receptors, respectively.
  • There is selective activation of 5-HT1 receptors due to antagonistic activity at 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 receptors. So, mirtazapine is also known as noradrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant (NSSA).
  • It also has H1 blocking property, but not anticholinergic or antidopaminergic properties.
  • Side effects include sedation, weight gain, dizziness, lipid abnormalities.
  • Sexual dysfunction is not a problem with this drug.

questions.text: Which of the following acts as partial/weak µ agonist + k antagonist on opioid receptors?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Buprenorphine

 

Option C:

 

Buprenorphine is unique among opioids as it acts as a partial agonist at the µ-opioid receptor and a weak antagonist at the κ-opioid receptor. Its partial agonist activity at the µ receptor allows it to produce analgesic effects similar to those of full agonists like morphine but with a ceiling effect that limits the maximum effect regardless of dose increase. This makes buprenorphine less likely to cause respiratory depression—a serious risk associated with full opioid agonists. Additionally, its weak antagonist activity at κ receptors may contribute to its effectiveness in treating addiction without providing the full euphoric effects that are typically sought by individuals using opioids.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Naloxone: This is a pure opioid antagonist, primarily used to reverse opioid overdose.

 

Option B. Naltrexone: Also an opioid antagonist, used in addiction treatment to block the effects of opioids and alcohol.

 

Option D. Nalmefene: An opioid antagonist used to manage alcohol dependence, not providing partial agonist effects at opioid receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Buprenorphine’s partial agonist action at µ-opioid receptors combined with its weak κ antagonism makes it an effective option for opioid addiction treatment, reducing potential abuse while managing withdrawal and dependence symptoms.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with a history of seizures presents to the clinic. He has been taking anticonvulsants for the last few years, and he reports experiencing visual disturbances, including a narrowing of his visual field. He is concerned about the possibility of permanent vision loss. Which of these anticonvulsants causes contraction of visual field?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vigabatrin

 

Option C:

 

Vigabatrin is an anticonvulsant known for its mechanism of action as a GABA transaminase inhibitor, which increases the level of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the brain, beneficial for controlling seizures. However, a significant side effect associated with vigabatrin is the contraction of the visual field, which can be severe and is often irreversible. This adverse effect necessitates regular and careful monitoring of visual function in patients using vigabatrin, particularly those who report visual disturbances, as these could indicate the onset of this irreversible side effect.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Levetiracetam: Does not commonly cause visual field changes.

 

Option B. Phenytoin: Known for different side effects, primarily affecting the CNS and skin, not specifically linked to visual field contraction.

 

Option D. Ethosuximide: Used primarily for absence seizures and does not typically cause visual field changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vigabatrin, while effective for controlling certain types of seizures, carries a risk of causing permanent visual field contraction, underscoring the need for regular ophthalmologic monitoring in patients undergoing this treatment.

choices.text: It is a specific antagonist of benzodiazepines.
It may be used to treat barbiturate poisoning.
It is given intravenously.
It acts on the same site on GABA channel where benzodiazepines bind.

questions.text: Mr. Atiq, a 40-year-old man, presents to the emergency department with symptoms of benzodiazepine overdose. He has a history of anxiety and has been taking benzodiazepines for several months. The medical team decides to administer flumazenil to reverse the effects of benzodiazepines. All the following statements about flumazenil are true EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It may be used to treat barbiturate poisoning.

 

Option B:

 

Flumazenil is a specific antagonist for benzodiazepines, meaning it reverses their effects by competitively binding to the benzodiazepine receptor site on the GABA-A receptor complex. It is administered intravenously, often in cases of overdose or to hasten recovery from benzodiazepine sedation in medical settings. Crucially, flumazenil does not counteract the effects of barbiturates, as these drugs do not act at the benzodiazepine binding site but rather have a distinct modulatory effect on the GABA-A receptor.

 

Explanation:

 

Options A, C, D: These statements correctly describe flumazenil’s pharmacological characteristics and mode of action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flumazenil is effective in reversing benzodiazepine effects but is not suitable for treating barbiturate poisoning due to different sites of action on the GABA-A receptor complex.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male with a history of depression and anxiety is started on escitalopram. After a week, he reports excessive drooling, vivid dreams, and mild nausea. He is concerned about these symptoms and asks you which of the following is not an adverse effect of escitalopram?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sialorrhea

 

Explanation:

 

  • Escitalopram belongs to a group of anti-depressant drugs called Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRI).
  • It is the active (S) enantiomer of citalopram.
  • Sialorrhea or excessive salivation is not a known adverse effect of escitalopram. It is important to remember from MCQ point that the only important drug used in CNS that causes sialorrhea is clozapine.
  • Vivid dreams and nausea are common side effects of escitalopram, and anorgasmia is a potential sexual side effect like all SSRIs.

questions.text: Dysphoria caused by opiates is mediated by which receptor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kappa

 

Explanation:

 

  • The dysphoria caused by opiates is mediated by the kappa opioid receptor. The kappa receptor is one of the three major classes of opioid receptors (the other two being mu and delta) and is found throughout the central and peripheral nervous systems.
  • When activated, the kappa receptor produces a variety of effects, including analgesia, dysphoria, and sedation. The dysphoric effects of kappa receptor activation are thought to be due to its effects on the reward pathway in the brain, which can lead to feelings of discomfort, anxiety, and aversion.
  • In contrast, activation of the mu opioid receptor is associated with the pleasurable effects of opioids, including pain relief and euphoria. The delta receptor is less well understood but is thought to play a role in the modulation of pain perception and mood.

questions.text: A 55-year-old teacher began to experience changes in mood. He was losing interest in his work and lacked the desire to play his daily tennis match. He was preoccupied with feelings of guilt, worthlessness, and hopelessness. In addition to the psychiatric symptoms, the patient complained of muscle aches throughout his body. Physical and laboratory tests were unremarkable. After 6 weeks of therapy with fluoxetine, his symptoms resolved. However, the patient complains of sexual dysfunction. Which of the following drugs might be useful in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mirtazapine

 

Explanation:

 

  • In this case, the patient has experienced sexual dysfunction as a side effect of fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Switching to another medication with a lower risk of sexual side effects may be helpful. Most typical antidepressants including SSRI, SNRI, MAO inhibitors and TCA can cause sexual adverse effects, so atypical antidepressant drugs are better option in this patient.

Other Options:

Option A,Option B and Option C : Fluvoxamine, Sertraline and Citalopram are SSRI which may also cause sexual side effects whereas Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that acts as an antagonist at alpha-2 adrenergic receptors and serotonin receptors (5-HT2 and 5-HT3). It has a lower risk of causing sexual side effects compared to SSRIs.
